unnormalised: A new study published in the "Journal of Mathematical Analysis" highlights a novel approach to solving complex differential calculus problems. Researchers at IIT Bombay have developed a method they claim can reduce computation time by up to 30% for certain types of equations. The study, funded by a grant of Rs. 50 lakh, focuses on applications of differential calculus in fields like fluid dynamics and control systems.
normalised: a new study published in the "Journal of Mathematical Analysis" highlights a novel approach to solving complex differential calculus problems. Researchers at I-I-T Bombay have developed a method they claim can reduce computation time by up to thirty percent for certain types of equations. The study, funded by a grant of rupee fifty lakh, focuses on applications of differential calculus in fields like fluid dynamics and control systems.

unnormalised: The technique involves a streamlined process for finding derivatives and integrals, using advanced numerical methods. According to Prof. Anjali Sharma, the lead researcher, "Our approach simplifies the process of solving equations with multiple variables. It allows for more accurate simulations and predictions. For example, the team used 10,000 iterations to validate their numerical method and to measure its error relative to analytical solutions."

This advancement is expected to impact fields ranging from aerospace engineering to climate modelling.
